div.head: FRIDAY, APRIL 28. 1905. ANOTHER RUSSIAN LOAN.
div.p: The most interesting news today is the announcement that the Russian Government has decided to raise another loan of 200 million marks owing to the poor success of the recent internal loan. There is no appeal to France this time, and the preliminaires have been arranged in Berlin. It has become perfectly plain that the French financiers, who were strongly opposed to the war from the very outset, are still more opposed to its continuance under the hopeless conditions to which Russia has been reduced. France has been unprecedentedly generous and confiding during the last ten years, though it must not be forgotten that the Russian Alliance gave her a feeling of security in Europe to which she had long been stranger, and for which she was willing to make the most handsome acknowledgments in her power. Her thrifty and frugal people hold Russian securities to the extent of four hundred milliona sterling —a stupendous sum in itself, and still more stupendous when one thinks of Russia’s financial status in the scale of the nations. During the lest twelve months France has found Russia fully thirty millions more. The Russians, therefore, cannot possibly complain that their ally has not trusted them. On the contrary, she has trusted them; if anything, too implicitly, and allowed her political gratitude to interfere considerably with strict business prudence.

Russia’s one financial hope now is Berlin, for the English market is closed to her, and the American regards Ruasian securities with equal disfavour. But Berlin finance plumes itself on its purely business principles strained dear of every extraneous sediment, and this morning’s telegram states that the terms of the new loans are to be inoreased in severity. But it is not probable that Germany will finance the war for Russia indefinitely, and if her reverses continue, it is unlikely many more loans will be raised. At the same time it is advisable to discount all the ill-considered talk and writing about the strain of the war upon the financial resources of the two belligerants. No well-informed person, of course, will dispute that war is very costly. It wastes both wealth and life ; it lessens production because it diverts both labour and capital from productive to unproductive employment ; it lessens confidence by causing apprehensions, and even scares ; and it adds to taxation. But the merely financial effects of war very soon pass away. In the present instance, and especially in the case of Russia, the real danger is to be found not in the financial, but in the sentimental influence which the struggle may have. She has a vast amount of gold at home, and she has the power to issue inconvertible paper to any extent she pleases. It is quite true, of course, that all this will tell upon the materiel condition of the people, and will be felt as a sore burden for a time. But it will be so chiefly, not because of the mere cost of the war itself, but because of the unfavourable economic condition of Russia when hostilities broke out. Owing partly to misgovernment, partly to the ignorance of the people themselves, partly to rash speculation, and partly to unfavourable seasons, Russia was in the throes of a long drawn-out crisis when the struggle began. The crisis was due immediately to bad seasons causing failure of the crops over a large part of the Empire, and it was intensified by rash industrial enterprise, injudicious loans by the bank, and of course, by the heavy taxation of the Government. The people consequently, are not in a state to bear any material addition to their burdens, and the war, therefore, will tell upon them, more than it otherwise would have done.

But even so, it is not the mere financial results so much as the possible sentimental effects that are to be dreaded. The whole population, as we have just been saying, is in deep distress, which is aggravated by the shock to credit and the disturbance given to all kinds of business by the war. In addition to that, misgovernment had driven a very considerable section, even of the Russians themselves, into a suppressed revolt, which every now and then demonstrates itself by the assassination of Ministers and other great officials. Outside of Russia proper, the Poles, the Finns, and the Armenians have been driven almost to madness by oppression ; and it is hardly necessary to add that the Jews are equally disaffected. As long as the army obeys orders the Government can maintain order, in spite of the almost universal disaffection. But if Russian reverses continue there is a possibility, though we doubt if it amounts to a probability, that a considerable part of the army may become disaffected. And in that case nobody can foresee what may happen. On the other hand, there is an equal possibility, and we think a greater probability, that the Government may be alarmed respecting the consequences if reverses continue in Manchuria, or if the armada of Rodjestvensky and Nebgotoff is destroyed, and that it may, therefore, enter upon a great policy of reform as the grandfather of the present Tsar did after the Crimean war. If this should happen, the war will prove to be a blessing in disguise, and its unfavorable , financial effects will soon pass away.

div.head: TO-DAY’S TELEGRAMS
div.p: UNREST IN RUSSIA.
ORGANISED HOOLIGANISM.
St. Petersburg, April 27.

A feeling akin to consterhation has been occasioned by rumours, reproduced by the leading newspapers, to the effect that 15,000 hooligans have organised themselves into bands with the object of attacking all so-called "intellectuals" found in the streets at Easter-tide. The authorities have taken elaborate precautions, and a special contingent of Don Cossacks has arrived here. There has been a general exodus of the aristocratic and middle classes over the holidays. Reports from the provinces indicate similar fears there, and especially in connection with the lst May, which is the Russian Easter Monday. General Trepoff in a proclamation assures the population that order will be presarved with the armed force if necessary.
(Reuter.)
ANOTHER RUSSIAN LOAN.
APPEAL TO GERMAN FINANCIERS.
St. Petersburg, April 27.

Owing to the poor success of the receut internal loan, Russia has decided to appeal to the German financiers for another loan of 200 million marks. The terms will be more severe than the former issues. The preliminaires have already been arranged in Berlin. (Reuter.)
THE ROYAL CRUISE.
VISIT TO NAPOLEON'S BIRTHPLACE Ajaccio, April 27. The King of England landed here, and visited Napoleon’s birthplace. (Reuter.)
MOROCCO. THE NEW BRITISH MINISTER. Tangiers, April 27. Mr. G. A. Lowther, the British Minister, is to proceed to Fez in about three weeks time in order to present his credentials. (Reuter).

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET. WAITING FOR NEBOGATOFF. STILL LINGERING NEAR KAMARANH.
div.p: Saigon, Aprir 27. The Russian Fleet is at present ranged in an arc of a circle between Cape Varela and the head of the peniusula of Kamaranh. It appears to be waiting for Nebogatoff's squadron. (R.)
London, April 27.
Telegrams from Saigon seem to indicate that the Baltic Fleet was still lingering in the vicinity of Kamaranh Bay yesterday morning.
(Reuter)

div.head: WHERE IS TOGO? MYSTERY SURROUNDING MOVEMENTS.
div.p: Tokio, April 27.
Formosa has been extensively fortified, but the puhlic is absolutely ignorant regarding Togo’s whoteahonts. The offioers and men have ceased communicating with their families. (R.)

div.head: AFGHANISTAN. GARRISONS REINFORCED.
div.p: London. April 27.
According to news received from Tashkent, the Afghan garrisons have been reinforced. A battery of heavy guns has arrived at Herat.

div.head: BRINK QUEST ON IN EGYPT. NATIVE OPINION.
div.p: The Cairo correspondent of “ Al Bassir" writes: — Many liquor merchants in Cairo and the provinces complain of the way in which their licenses are being taken from them by the authorities on the ground that it is in accordance with the circular issued by the Ministry of the Interior. If this is so it is very strange, for a license once granted and delivered should not be withdrawn without good reason, but if the Government should think proper to do so at least it should refund the amount paid for the license. I am told that a cafe keeper sold his cafe to another man; the buyer applied for a liscnese, but the Government refused to grant one; the applicant protested, but the Government persisted, and at last he was told that if be wished to go on with the cafe he should allow it to remain in the name of the former proprietor, and induce him to stay with him there. If a license was given to the former owner why should it not be given to the new comer as well? Both offer similar guarantees and are of the same profession.

If it is the intention of our Government to suppress the safe of alcoholic drinks by this treatment we must thank them and wish them all success in their efforts; but this is not the wav bring about the end desired. A heavy tax should be imposed on alcoholic liquors; if the tax he not paid in time then the place should be closed, as is the case in the Sudan and in America, where the Government also makes it a condition that liquors of bad quality are liable to be confiscated and spoiled, and the place closed. Under these conditions the sale of intoxicants would be greatly diminished, and the quality of liquors be kept at a high grade.

The plan followed by our Government of withdrawing a license or delaying to grant one, has no effect whatever, especially when the applicant depends upon a foreign authority; and acts in accordance with orders received from his own consul exclusively. What could the Government do with such a person if he persisted in opening his shop, whether he had previously obtained a license or whether a license bad been refused.

div.head: THE SALE OF HASHISH.
div.p: A correspondent writes:- I think it is as well to contradict a misstatement in a letter in your Wednesday’s issue, in which it is stated that the sale of hashish has been eliminated from the market. On the contrary it is well known that this article has never been so cheap nor so easily obtained as at present. The Coastguard officers, it is true, receive £4.000 a year in prize money, but it is sold afterwards, it is believed, by the ill-paid Coastguard "Tommy," who only gets a pittance of four dollars a month. Unless a heavy penalty is placed on hashish it will continue to be a moveable commodity, shifting backward and forward between those who seize it as contraband and those who sell it to the small captains of the wooden crafts in port who manage to convey it into town for sale. It most be hoped that the "white slaves" will not pass from hand to hand in a similar manner. They will certainly be harder to keep dark than the noxious herb.

div.p: All the Ministries are to be closed on Shem en Neesim (May 1).
The Brindisi Mail will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 8.30 a.m. on Sunday.

div.head: Polo.
div.p: — Owing to the races, there will be polo on the A.S.C. grounds on Monday at 12 noon instead of in the afternoon.

div.head: Street Asphalting
div.p: - The P.W.D. will asphalte the Han Khalil, Gamalieh, and Bab el Sharieh streets of Cairo next month.

div.head: Sir Wm. Garstin’s Report.
div.p: —The National Printing Office has commenced printing the Arabic translation of Sir Wm. Garstin’s report on the Upper Nile.

div.head: Mex.
div.p: —The season at Mex is now getting into full swing. An excellent orchestra plays at Prinea’s Cafe and the last tram leaves Mex for the city at 10 p m.

div.head: Army of Occupation.
div.p: — It is announced in yesterday’s Army Orders that Brigadier General G. M. Bullock, C.B., has adorned command of the troops in Egypt, with effect from 16th March, 1905.

div.head: A Deserter
div.p: —The Gouvernorat has condemned a policeman to 42 days’ hard labour and 20 strokes of the kourbash for having deserted. Another policeman was sent to prison for six months on a charge of theft.

div.head: Basdmann Opera Company.
div.p: —On Sunday next, at 9 p.m., a performance of "The Toreador" will be given on behalf of the Israelite Free Schools by the members of the Ban Imann Opera Company at the Khedivial Opera House.

div.head: Simi es Nessim Trips.
div.p: —The Railway Administration intend putting on two extra trains between Punt Limoun and Marg, and running a numbor of special trains between Cairo and the Barrage, on Shem en-Nessim.

div.head: A New Music Hall for Alexandria
div.p: is to be built on the site now occupied by the Eden Theatre. The land has been let for ten years to the proprietor of the Eiffel Tower chantant. Suez Canal.- 9 ships passed through the Canal on the 25th inst., 4 of which were Britiih, 2 Dutch, 1 French, 1 Russian, 1 Turkish. The receipts for the day were frs. 232,452.01,. making the total from the lst jnst. fre. 8,487,430.72.

div.head: Tokar Syndicate.
div.p: —Application has made to the London Stock Exchange to appoint a special settling day in Tokar (Sudan) Prospecting Syndicate, 5,000 shares of £1 each, fully paid, Nos. 1 to 5,000.

div.head: Hardly a Qualification.
div.p: — A member of the Stock Exchange who has just come out to Egypt in the interests of a large Anglo-Egyptian house was asked whether he could talk Egyptian. "No," was the reply, "but I can play pyramids."

div.head: Jewel Thief Captured.
div.p: - The Cairo police have succeded in laying hands on the man who stole two brilliants valued at £250 from Carissian’s jewelery establishment the other day. His name is Farid Maricius, and he holds an official position in Khartoum.

div.head: Imperial Ottoman Bank.
div.p: — The agencies of this bank in Egypt will shortly be transferred from the control of the Constintinople headquarters of the Bank and placed under the direct control of the London and Paris committees, more especially of the former.

div.head: An Electrical Spinning Mill.
div.p: —Tlw Acme Spinning Company are building, at Pendlebury, near Manchester, a mammoth mill, to be called the "Acme," which will contain about 80,000 spindles, and will cost, with equipment, nearly £100,000. It will be the first spinning-mill in Lancashire to be electrified.

div.head: Murderer Sentenced.
div.p: —The Native Court of Appeal has condemned to death Mohamed Ali El Naggar, of Kotodr (Gharbieh), for the murder of one Aly Ismail Abu Shadi. The wife of the murdered man allowed the murderer to enter the house and Ismail was killed by a blow from a hatchet while he slept.

div.head: Egyptian Paleoliths.
div.p: —Mr. H.R. Hull has been searching, in company with Mr. E. R. Ayrton, for paleoliths in the Western Thebaid, and has published in "Man" for March selection from his discoveries, which he compares very effectively with some British specimens. They support the affirmative side of the question whether real paleoliths have been found in Egypt.

div.head: A Slump.
div.p: — In financial circles yesterday; evening rumours were in circulation, that compliostions had occurred in regard to Morocco. Private telegrams, which were received on the subject, showed that the London and Paris Exchanges had been adversely affected, something of a slump having taken place. The absence of any confirmation of the rumours in either Reuter or Havas's wires this morning, however, and the firmer tone in Europe, tends to show that the slump was purely a Stock Exchange maneovure. It is lucky that the local Bourse was closed to day, as some excitable spirits might have been led away by these rumours. The chance of a great European war at the present moment is very remote, and there is extremely little likelihood that the Morooco question should enter on an acute phase at the very moment of the King's vitit to Paris.

div.head: THE TRADE OF EGYPT. MARCH RETURNS.
div.p: The value of the imports into Egypt during last month is given in the Customs returns as LE. 1,674,052. This figure exceeds the total for the corresponding month last year by LE. 57,985. This is very significant, for March, 1904, was an exceptionally prosperous mouth as regards the import returns, they having exceeded the total returns for the previous March by LE. 354,574, or 28 percent. If last month Egypt succeeded in increasing this by nearly LE. 60,000, it shows the extraordinary prosperity of the country. We have drawn special attention to the comparison, because March, 1904, was exceptional, the great increase in imports being the inevitable consequence and indication of the profits made by the country on the cotton crop, which realised the highest prices of recent years. The high price last year formed a purely adventitious factor in this prosperity, and it would therefore have been no matter for surprise if we had to register a decline during last month from the maximum figures of foreign trade, which would only have been a legitimate reaction. But instead of such a reaction we find that last month, with cotton far below last year’s prices, Egypt increased her total imports by nearly LE. 60,000 over March, 1904. The permanent expansion of trade is surely the safest criterion of the country's progress.
For the first quarter of the year the exccess over 1904 is LE. 552,985. The excess of that quarter over the corresponding period in 1903 was LE. 431,460.

The exports amounted to LE. 1,924,770, a decrease of LE. 366,133 on March last year. The cotton exports totalled LE. 1,445,331, a decrease of LE. 432,148 on the figures for March in the corresponding year. The total value of the cotton exported during the first quarter was LE. 193,225, a decrease of LE. 1,963,361 on the same period last year.

div.head: DAIRA SANIEH COMPANY.
div.p: The report for 1904 shows a profit of £9.805, as compared with £28,807 for 1903 (which included the difference betweeit the price paid to the Daira Sanieh Administration and the ammount realised by the sale of the factories). With the balance of £9,506 brought forward from the previous year, there is now a total amount to credit of profit and loss of £19,312. It is proposed to declare a dividend of 3s. each on the ordinary shares, leaving to be carried forward £1,612. The total sales of land (including the those made by the Daira Sanieh Administration) up to December 31, 1904, amounted to 287,003 feddans and £E 11,064,427, to which must be added for the factories (exclusive of land) £E 11,815,677. Sales from December 31, 1904, March 31, 1905, have amounted to £E 10,275, making a total of £E11,825,952 The lands still remaining to be sold amount to 92 feddans, of on etimated value of £El4,150.

div.head: COTTON COMMISSION FEES. HEAVY FINES IN LIVERPOOL.
div.p: There was considerable stir upon the Liverpool cotton flags when it became known that board of directors of the Cotton Association had, after prolonged investigation, decided to inflict a fine of £1,000 each on two members of the association, who have been buying broker. The said brokers have, it is said, seriously broken the rules and regulations of the association as to comission charges for buying cotton futures. Four spinners who are associate members of the association are implicated, and havo been fined £250 each. It seems the two brokers have not been charging the usual fees for purchasing futures, in the hope of securing the spot buisness of the four spinning firm.

div.head: SUDAN COTTON GROWING.
div.p: Cotton-growing in the Sudan for export purposes cannot as yet be said to have passed out of the experimental stage. The reports on the cotton-growing possibilities of the country are satisfactory, but it remains to be proved whether it can be grown in any quantity under the existing limitations as regards irrigation. Nothing can be done to improve, to any great extent, the water-supply of the Sunden until Mr. Dupuis' report has been received and fully considered. The question of railway communication, which is equally important to that of water-supply, will have received a partial solution when the Nile Red Sea Railway is completed.

div.head: DISCOVERY OF LIGNITE.
div.p: A deposit of lignite has been found in the province of Dongola, and the question of whether it is of sufficient extent to be of any general use is now being investigated. The report on samples sent to London by the Nubia Sudan Development Company has proved so satisfactory that the directors have decided to start operations on the east bank of the Nile, opposite the town of Dongola, and a diamond-drill has been brought up for this purpose.

div.head: DISAPPEARING LANDMARKS.' ZARANI’S CAFE LEASED.
div.p: One after another the theatres of Alexandria are going, and now it is the turn of the cafes to disappear. The Zizinia Theatre has been disposed of and will, it is said, have to make room for the palatial additions which the Splendid Hotels Company intend to graft on the New Khedivial Hotel. The site of the Alhambra Theatre is only awaiting a purchaser to be turned into flats or offices. The Abbas Helmy Theatre has been burnt down, and it has not been decided to erect another theatre on the site. New Zarani’s Cafe which is undoubtedly the finest cafe in Egypt, is to disappear. The Alexandria Exchange Company have leased the place and its appurtenances to Messrs. Thos. Cook and Son (Egypt) Limited, for a number of years. Messrs. Cook intend making it their offices at Alexandria for not only their tourist buisness but also for their engineering department, their forwarding business, etc. It is one of the most commanding sites in Alexandria and we congratulate Messrs. Cook on their enterprise in having acquired this excellent property for a term of years on what, we understand, are favorable terms.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: H.H. the Khedive gave audience yesterday to H.E. Mirza All Asghar Khan, Persian Diplomatic Agent, who presented M.M. Taimed Danlah Dir, Mirza Mahdi Khan, proprietor of "El Hikmat," Mihran Khan, Persian Consul at Alexandria, Mohamed Tayeb Bey, secretary to the Persian Diplomatic Agency, and Agha Mohamed Ali Rashti, a well known Persian merchant of Alexandria, who thanked his Highness for the distinctions that he bad been pleased to confer on, them.

His Highness visited the El Mardam Mosque, in the Darb el Ahmar quarter, for prayers this morning. The "Moayad" points out that this big mosque has been abandoned for the last thirty-six years owing to the state of decay in which it was. The Wakfs Administration has lately of the command of the Khedive, completely repaired it at a cost of over LE 30,000.

A guard of honor, composed of 2 officers, 100 rank and file, band, and regimental colour of the 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, will parade at the central railway station, Cairo, at 7.25 a.m. on Thursday, 4th May, on the occasion, of the departure of his Highness for Alexandria His Highness will hold his first reception at Ras el Tin on Saturday, May 6.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: Among the deciscions taken by the Council of Ministers yesterday are the following:
1. A decree was signed consenting to the formation of the Societe Egyptienle d'enterprises urbaines et rurales.
2. The Charkieh Provincial Conncil is convoked for May 8, to elect a delegate to the Legislative Council

div.head: ALEXANDRIA LINER DAMAGED.
div.p: Early in the morning of Wednesay this week a collision occurred in the Firth of Clyde between the steamer "Jeranos," 1,286 tons, and the Ellerman liner "Adalis," 2, 482 tons, the former outward bound from Glasgow for Alexandria, and the latter inward bound from Alexandria. The "Jeranos" was so badly damaged that she was compelled to return to Glasgow with the forepeak full of water The "Adalia" was damaged amidships.

div.head: THE S.S. "CANDLESHOE".
div.p: Port Said, Wednesday.

This morning, at 6 o’clock, I proceeded on board this vessel and found that already a very considerable portion 7 of the cargo of rice had beea discharged during the night. It was all quite spoilt by fire, smoke, and water. The seat of the conflagration was apparent in one corner of the ’tween decks of No. 2 hold, where now nothing is to be seen but charred and blackened bags of ruined rice.

Several hold beams, and frames are much damaged by heat, and excluding the value of the cargo, which is practically speaking quite spoiled in that hold, I should ray the damage to the ship is very considerable.
The vessel is fully insured, I understand, and the damaged cargo will, in so far as the water-damage is concerned,come under the “General Average" clause.
There is still a large quantity of water in the holds and the ship in consequence has a heavy list, which, however, is not dangerous. The work of discharging still goes on.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. “Persian Prince” left Malta for Alexaudria via Tripoli (Barbary) on Thursday last, with generol cargo, and e.

div.head: “THE HOLY CITY"
div.p: On Tuesday last, an eflective rendering of Gaul’s sacred cantata “The Holy City"'was-given in St. Mark's Church by the choir, augmented, by members of the choir of All Saints', Ramleh, under the steady and able conductorship of Mr. William Smith. It is perhaps to be regretted that the openingvquartet was not sung as such, as a somewhat overpowering result was produced, by singing it in "full," which detracted from the general effect evidently intended by this beautiful piece of harmony. It would obviously be invidious to pick out any individual rendering from among the solo work, as it was evident the soloists had taken great pains, and one and all gave great pleasure in the numbers that bad been allotted them. Miss MunGavin was heard with great effect in the solo, “He that overcometh.” and the trio, "At Eventide it shall be light," sung by Mrs. Baylis, Miss Callender, and Mrs. Roberts, was rendered with a great appreciation of the spint in which both words and music are so happily combined. Tho quartet and chorus, "List! the Cherubio Host," over which a bass solo was exocellently sung by Mr. Percy Smith, gave great pleasure, and by no means the least effective feature was the “Harp", accompaniment played on the piano by Mr. Crofton in a manner which quite made up for the absence of the instrument originally intended. Mention must also be made of the duet between Miss Calendar and Mrs. Roberts, which in the, opinion of some, was the most thoroughly artistic piece of singing of the evening. Mr. W.F. Sarjeant and Mr. J. Purvis were admirable in what they had been given to do, and last in order, though possibly first in importance, must we mention the steady playing of the organist, Mr. Heaton, who contributed very largely to the success of what was universally pronounced a most enjoyable and musically performance of undoubetdly beautiful work. As regards the singing of the choruses, it is not so easy to speak. The basses were a trifle weak and there was a certain lack of "attack" noticeable, but the sopranos did very good work. There will be another performance of this cantata in All Saints' Church, Ramleh, on Tuesday, May 2, at 6.30 p.m.

div.head: To The Editor of the Egyptian Gazette
div.p: Dear Mr. Editor, - I quite agree with "Harmony" that your scanty report regarding Tuesday 'recital' at St. Marks showed a great want of taste and courtesy towards those who gave up their time, talent, and gifts for weeks towards making the show of the afternoon a success. The cursory reference by the writer to the choir, and the prominence given to the tablet and persons present at the unveiling cannot but give one the idea that he knows which side his bread is buttered, but he may make a mistake.- Yours truly,
Accord.
Alexandria, 28 April.

[Our columns being open to all our readers we publish our correspondent's letter, but we must again point out that the above specially written criticism of the cantata was only held over owing to want of space. The writer of the general report of the proceedings and that of the criticism are two seperate individuals. Ed E.G.]

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Sir Reginald Wingate is expected to arrive in Cairo about the middle of next month.
Sir William Garstin will leave for Snakin and Bandar es Sudan about the middle of next week in order to inspect the works in progress at the new port. Afterwards Sir William will go to Khartoum.

People who have seen Lady Howe since her return from Egypt declare she looks all the better for the change, but at the same time she is very far from well, and likely to be an invalid for some time to come.
Mr. and Mme. Barois have been spending their Easter in Palestine.
Captain and Quartermaster A. White, 2nd Rifle Brigade, and Captain E.S. Moars, A.S.C., have been granted leave of absence.

Major Bailey, a younger son and Lord Glannusk, is to be best man to Captain Kenrick tomorrow, when he marries Miss Helen Little. Both officers belong to the 11th Hussars and any number of officers past and present have preuxxxxxx to attend the ceremony, which takes place at St. Mary Abbot's, Kensington. Lord and Lady Edmund Talbot, Colonel and Mrs. Qabert Lumley and others connected with the regiment have sent wedding presents, while the colonel and officers now serving have presented Captain Kendrick with a silver statue representing a trooper of the 11th Hussars.

Mr. and Mrs. Max Steinauer came down to Alexandria from Cairo yesterday and embark for Athens today on their honeymoon. On Wednesday night they occupied the rooms known as the Empress "Eugenie's" suite at Ghezireh Palace.

div.head: STEINAUER-BREWSTER WEDDING:
div.p: We publish today a further list of presents recieved by Mr. and Mrs. Steinauer on the occasion of their wedding, for which we had not space in our issue of yesterday;-

div.head: WEDDING AT PORT SAID
div.p: Port Said, Wednesday.

To-day was celebrated the marriage of Miss Victorine Reichmaun with Mr. Paul Bouvier, and employe of the Suez Canal Company at Ismailia. The bride is the second daughter of Mr. Reichmaun, the superintendent of Messrs. Will and Co's coaling department. The legal ceremony was held at the Consukate yesterday at 4 p.m. and to-day punctually at 10 a.m., the bride and her family arrived at the church (St. Eugenie) at which the religious ceremony was held in the presence of the Governor of Port Said, the French Consul, and many other dignatories. After the ceremony the bridal party and the guests drove to the Eastern Exchange, where covers had been prepared for 180 people. The dejeuner was served on the verandab, which was very prettily decorated. The "garcons d'bonueur" and their accompanying demoiselies headed the precession after the bride and bridegroom, and consisted of the following:- Mr. Homery with Mlle C. Reichmann, Mr. J. Psalty with Mlle M. Zamut, Mr. E. Brest with Mlle M. Perrin, Mr. J. Allouard with Mlle C. Broquedir, Mr. Colombani with Mlle Y. Cipeck. They all carried exquisite bouquets. At 3 p.m. dancing commenced and continued all the afternoon and evening until 10 p.m. The newly-wedded pair left by 6.45 p.m. train for Cairo amidst cheers and showers of confetti.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE, APRIL 28, 1905. COMMISSION MUNICIPALE
div.p: ( Communication Officielle ) I* Commission Municipale s'ost réunie le 26 avril 1905 à 1 h. p.m. sous U présidence de S. K. Mahmoud Pacha Sidky. Présente MM. Amb. A. Ralli, vice-président. Abdel Moneirn Boy Dabi Ahmed Boy Yehia, B. Benaohi, Hussein Bey Riax, L. Eacotl'wr, P. Fonder!, K W. P. Foster,. Mansour Boy You»-sef, Baron A. de Mena-ice, 0. Rothaker; A. PadoaBey, Dr Schiess Bey, B. Stross, T. 8uz rarini, Dr G. Valonsin, G. Zervudachi membres, W. P. Chataway, administrateur, 1. Sedky Bey, secrétaire. Les procès-verbaux delà Commission Muni oipale des 22 lévrier et 1er Mars 1905 sont adoptés. Mention est faite de l’envoi and tous les mem bres des prooèe-verbaux de la Délégation du 21 . mars au 11 avril 1905. Ahmed Bey Yohia dit que les habitants du Caire tant indigènes qu’européens ont tenu à célébrer dignement le centenaire de l’avènement an trône du Grand Mebemet Aly. La ville d’Alexandrie qui doit à cet illustre souverain la plus grande part de sa prospérité actuelle ne saurait laisser passer l'anniversaire d'uc évènement aussi heureux, sans manifester sa raoonnaissanoe d'une façon éclatante. La statue do Mebemet Aly érigée sur la plus, belle place de cette ville est la consécration des bienfaits sans nombre que. le fondateur de la dyn«tii-a prodigués à notre cité et témoigne ddf l'attachement qu’il avait pour La Municipalité d’Alexandrie qui représente indistinctement les habitants de oetto ville, sera certainement heureuse, après avoir généreusement contribué à l'établissement d'une fondation industrielle qui doit porter le nom de Mehemet Aly, de participer oomrne il oonvient dans les fêles qui amont données dans cette circonstance’ mémorable. Ahmed Bey Yehia propose à oet effet l’ouverture d'un crédit de LR 1,000. L’unanimité des membres de la Commission remercie Yehia Bey pour avoir exprimé un sentiment qui répond à un désir qui les anime toux Mais l'Assemblée oonsidère que son devoir en la circonstance ne dort pas se traduire par une simple collaboration mais qu'elle doit h sa situation, de prendre «Ile-mémo l'initiative des fêtes à célébrer et de recueillir les concours que ne manquera pas de provoquer dans le public l'importance de l’évènement k commémorer. Elle ouvre dans ce but un orédit de I*R 1,000 auxquels s’ajoutera le montant des souscriptions déjà ouvertes parmi la population. La Commission présidera, oomrno Comité, toute entière à l'organisation des fêtes et s'adjoindra parmi les pereonhos étrangères à son sein, les notabilités dont le oonoours ne peut manquer de lui être utile. Un sous-comité, oomposé de MM. Yehia Bey, do Menasoe et Zervudachi/ oit chargé des détails d’organisation, et pourra lui aussi se faire assister par toute collaboration étrangère à la Commission. / Communication' est donnée de deux lettres de 8. K le Ministre de l’Intérieur transmettant les remarques faites par les Départements des Finanoes, des Travaux Publics et des Servions Sanitaires au sujet du règlement sur la vente des biens défis Municipalité, arrêté par la Commission dans sa séance du 22 février dernier. L'Assemblée adopte à ce sujet les observations de son Comité du Contentieux et décide de les transmettre au Ministère. Elle oompte W uno prompte approbation do oe règlement en vue de la mise en vente des terrains. Communication est également donnée d’une lettre do 8. R le Ministre de l’Intéiiour''retournant avec quelques modifications de détail, le règlement sur leschicns et la rage, en vue de son application provisoire jusqu'à la promulgation d'un règlement pour toute l’Egypte actuellement eu voie d’élaboration. La Commission an été son règlement, en conséquence, mais elle estime que celui-ci devra avoir un caractère définitif, à moins que i'Anemblée s'inspirant des dispositions qui seront prises par le Gouvernement, ne juge opportun d'apporter des modifications à son propre règlement Lecture est donnée d’une dépêche de S. E. le Ministre de l’Intérieur informant qu’il approuve la décision de la Commission relative à la réorganisation des servi oe*. Il est également donné lecture d’une lettre de S. B. le Ministre de l'Intérieur portant certaines observations au sujet du règlement sur la taxe des voitures et bestiaux. Ls Commission adopte à co sujet ûne note de sou Comité du Contentieux mais pour oe qui concerne le relèvement de la taxe sur les voitures numérotées, il est entendu qu’il ne sera appliqué qu’à partir do 1906. Sur la proposition de M. Esooffisr, la Commission décide de mettre à l'étude un projet de suppression graduelle des tombereaux à deux roues, en raison des dégradation* qu’ils font subir aux voies publiques et leur remplacement par des charrettes à quatre roues ainsi que l'établissement d'une règle fixant la largeur des jantes des charroi*. Relativement aux automobiles, la Commission se rapporte à la vigilanoe de la polioe pour empêcher les vitesses exagérées dans les rues populeuses. Lecture est donnée de deux lettres de 8. B. le Ministre de l’Intérieti- ot de la direction des services saniUjrse-AU *ujet de la question de la pollution dès eaux lu canal Mahmoudieb. La Commission piend note de oe que sur la recommandation des services sanitaire», la Détégàtfotf a demandé aux' service* un devis podr le remplacement du canal do dérivation du Farkba par une oonduite formée en fer qui amènerait l’eau directement des pompes du canal Mahmoodieh à l’usine de* Baux. La Commission sur la proposition de la Délégation décide l’ouverture de* crédite suivants : L.B, 600, à prélever *nr le budget extra- ordinaire, pour les travaux de modification et d’entretien nécessaires pour le jardin Nouiha jusqu'à la fin de l'année. L E. 393, à prélever sur le même budget, pour l'octroi de gratifications aux percepteurs. La somme nécessaire à ces gratifications devra être prévue dans le budget ordinaire de chaque année. L.E. 4.879 à prélever sur le budget extraordinaire en vue de faire face à l’excédent de crédits que néoeasito lo programme de oon foctiou de nouvelles routes cette année. L. E 1,251, à prélever sur le solde disponible de l’emprunt, ponr l’exécution da complément du oollecteur Est à partir de la Porte Rosette jusqu’au Rond-Point delà Compagnie des Eaux, travail adjugé par la Délégation.à M. Gerakis. * LE. 300 à prélever sur le budget extraordinaire, pour une allocation à la veuve de M. r mio Bey, ancien directeur du servioe de la propriété bâtie, décédé. Sur le rapport do Comité des Finances et la proposition de la Délégation, la Commission approuve les oomptos de 1'exercioe 1904 ainsi que lee propositions de l'administrateur qui les accompagnent La Commission ratifie l'entente oonolne par le Comité spécial dos plantations avec M-André, ingéuieur paysagiste. Celui oi recevra L.B. 600 pour la oonfeotion lo* plans, lie vis etc. relatifs à la transformation m parcs des fortifications et terrains adjaoents iitnéa des deux oôtéa de la Porte Rosette. La -omise des dits documents devra avoir lieu ivant le 15 octobre prochain. La Commission décidera si M. André devra lonner les premières indications en oe qni oon »rne ia mise en train dn travail, auquel il lui lera alloué LE. 150, tous frais compris, pour e séjour d'un mois environ qu'il fera à Alexandrie dans oe but A oette oooasion, la Commission se référant iu vœu émis par le Comité des Finances, lors le l'examen du budget de 1905, et en prévi-lion dos travaux doi parcs qui auront besoin i'-une direction spéciale, décide la nomination l'on jardinier paysagiste dans la classe de LE. 22 à 26. Un oonoours sera ouvert à cet effet. La Commission approuve le rapport du Co-nité des travaux publics tondant à renvoyer es propositions de MM. Cumbo et Zoifro ro-atives au badigeonnage ot aux enduits'des liaisons jusqu’au moment de l’élaboration du -èglement sur lee constructions actuellement à 'étude. f _ ‘ ..." La Commission autorise l’administration à ia ter en justice dans diverse» affaires jndi-siairas. Le projet de règlement intérieur est ren-royé à nouveau a^TÜ5ttlj8\de réorganisation qui invitera les auttBTïBemlwes de l’Assemblée Plénière à une réunion oh chacun pourra dé-relopper ses objections en vuo d'arriver à une mtente sur lo texte avant de le soumettre à la Jommissiou. Sur udo interpellation de M. Esooffier, l’administrateur répond que le lotissement des terrains de Chatoy est achové, qu'il a été approuvé par 1e Conseil du i'auxim et sera soumis ians le oourant de la semaine à l’approbation lu Ministère des Travaux Publics. Eu vue de ne pas perdre de temps la Commission prie le Comité d’évaluation d'établir le pins têt possible la valeur iuitialo des lots pour la mise a prix et invite l’administration à préparer en même temps les projets de cahier des charges pour oe* terrains, lesquels seront soumis à la Commission. En raison dè oe que quelques membres s’étaient retirés, et le quorum ne permettant plus la continuation des délibérations, la Commission ajourne pour la prochaine séaooe l’examen de l’interpellation de M. Bscoffier sur la question de rétablissement d’nne baraque en bois au terminus dè la ligne de Ramleh. La séance est levée à 7 h. 1/2 p.m.

div.head: LES MAISONS ECONOMIQUES Ét LES CITES-JA.RDINS
div.p: M. Bourgeois, directeur de la Cio du Gaz, a fait mercredi soir à l’Université Populaire une conférence sur les maisons économiques. En parlant des premiers efforts tentés ici pour trancher cette question épineuse, il oonstate l’abord que les promotéars ont fait fausse route en s’adreesaat aux autorités administratives. M. Bourgeois veut qu’on s’adresse à l’i-nitiative privée, qn’on éveille dans le peuple les sentiments de solidarité et de coopération, jt à l’appui de sa thèse il oite les résultats obtenus de oette façon en Europe et surtout en Angleterre oh de grands philanthropes s’occupent de faire œavra durable. Quant au meilleur système à adopter, l’émi-aent conférencier se déclare à juste titre contre les fameux blocs préconisés par M. Al-lereon et la commission des locataires et appe-és à devenir des oentree de contagion et de naladies; il se prononoe au (contraire en faveur le la maison aveo jardin proposée par M. Zouro et qoe noua avons à diverses reprises recommandée dans notre journal. Les distances ont dLpara aujourd’hui grâœ aux rapides moyens de teansports.ct'iï n’y a plus de raison de se grouper oomrne autrefois dans des oentre* populeux et malsain*. M. Bourgeois voudrai t dono qu’on «construisit su Mex et à Kom el-Dik des cités jardins à l’instar de oelles qui ont déjà fait leurs preuves en Angleterre pour leur supériorité hygiénique, économique, récréative et morale. On élèverait des maisons à on seul étage, qni, le jardin et 1a oour (compris, occuperaient une superficie totale de 444 mètres (carrée. En sup posant à ces terrains une valeur moyenne de 300 LE. le feddau, l’emplaoement nécessaire ne coûterait brut que 80 LE. et 40 LE. tout nivelé. La construction, qni se «composerait de 5 ch*mbres,reviendrait à LE. 180, soit en tout 220 LR qui, an taux de 5 %, représenteraient un loyer de 11 LB. per an, «oit I P.T. per jour. Bu payant un loyer de LE 21 1/2par an, soit 7 P.T. par jour, le locataire deviendrait propriétaire an bout de 15 années. Non* n’avons pas l’espace voulu pour donner à cette intéressante conférouoa tout le déve loppement qu’elle mérite, mais qn’il nous suffise aujourd’hui de dire que voilà uo beau champ ouvert pour l’intiative privée sane sacrifice d'argent de sa part, puisque la om-binaison ci-dessus rapporterait du 4 %.

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT. POSTS AND TELEGRAPHS DEPARTMENT. NOTICE
div.p: Tenders will be received the Office of the Director of Posts and Telegraphs, Khartoum, up to 12 noon on Thursday the lst June 1905 for the purchase of the following Postage Stamps:- (defaced) Sudan Postage Stamps face value about .............................. Persons wishing to tender can consult the Specification at the above Office any day from 9 a.m. l p.m. except Fridays and General Holidays. Tendors must be submitted on stamped paper: they should be addreesed to the Director of Posts and Telegraphs, in a sealed envelope bearing the inscription “Tenders for purchase of Obliterated Sudan Postage Stamps.” The above Sudan Stamps can also be obtained in complete sets at the rate of 50 m/m a set but not less than four sets can be sold. The Director of Posts and Telegraphs does not bind bimself to accept the highest or any tender. (Signed) H. L Mackworth, Bimb., E. A. Asst-Director of Posts and Telegraphs. Khartoum, 6th April 1905.

div.head: To the holders of Share Warrants to Bearer of THE EGYPTIAN DELTA LIGHT RAILWAYS, LIMITED. Proposed issue or 19,308 further 5 1/2 % Cumulative Preference Shares or £10 each.
div.p: The Board of Directors of the above company are proposing to ofer the above Shares at the price of 12.20.0 per share pro rata to those exisitng Proprietors who are known to the Company in the proportion of one new SHare for every five shares already held. In order that a form of offer with full particulars only filled in with form of acceptance attached may be issued to holders Share Warrants to bearer, those holders of Warrants who wish to participate are hereby notified that they must first deposit their Warrants either at the London Office of the Company 211/214 Gresham House, Old Broad Street, E.C. or at the National of Egypt, Cairo or Alexandria, or if that is inconvenient the Warrants can be deposited with some registered Bankers who will issue a Certificate in exchange stating that they hold the Warrants on acoount of the Depositors with their names and addresses and the particulars of the Warrants deposited and will continue to hold the same until after the 26th April, in which case such Banker’s Certificate can be lodged at the London Office of the Company or at the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo or Alexandria in lieu of the bearer Warrants themselves.

Deposits must be made in banking hours between the 15th April and the 26th April j 1905 (both dates inclusive) when the form of offer above referred to and form of acceptance attached, together with a reciept for the warrants or Bankers certificate will be issued to the Depositor. Deposited Warrants will be handed out against receipt at any time after the said 26th April 1905. With the above mentioned acceptance , applications may also be made for any surplus Shares not taken up by shareholders to the foil pro rata amount to which they are entitled.
By order of the Board,
F.J. Horne,
Secretary.

div.head: PHARMACY IN EGYPT.
div.p: LORD CROMER’S REPLY. MEETING AT ALEXANDRIA. An important meeting of the International Society of Pharmacists of Alexandria will be held on Tuesday next in order to read Lord Cromer’s reply to the pharmacists in regard to the new regulations, and to discuss matters of general interest appertaiuing to thg profession, 'lhe following réoumiS of tho «ituation will be , of iuterestiin view ot this meeting. Tho proteste of tho Pharmaoentioal Socie-tie» of Cairo and Alexandrin againat certain causes of the new Pharmacy Régulations, eui n'otably against Clause II., haviog failed t ■ aiove the autborittea, it wae reeolved, u a last resource, that the membera shonld appeal to théir respective diplomatio agente, and a pétition was drawn up, whioh atated in etfect that the new Pharmacy Law for Egypt, publiahed in September last by the Sahitaiÿ Authonty, and approved by the Jlixed Court of Appeal at Alexandria, had raised just proteatatiotis on the part Of the qualified pbannaciate. lt waa admitted that the new law was a real stop towarda progrès», but that Clause IL took away pharmacy irom the real pharmaciste and deliver-ed it over to commerce and spéculation, mmstuuch as it autboriaed auy person to ;urry on a pharmacy and to selland prépare mcdicines »o long as a qualitiod cbemiat *\i in charge.-It waa pointed ont that in ïuch a case, the qualitiod man mnst submit to every caprioe of the capitalist and that .«iween the two tbere must exist a certain ittagouism, which .would be to the pnblio ■runent. On the other hand, qualified damnais without much capital would fiud iittle’ or no opportnnity of astablishing thern-wlvw on thoir own acoount. No Européen pbarmaceutioal législation, it was shuiiirn, makes mention of such an inegu.anty/Even Turkey (under Capitulations hke Egy (it) takes o exception tb the rnle that the qualified chemist has alone the right to open and to canyon a pharmacy. The International Associations of Caire and Alexandria there-foie drsired to protest againatr Article II., and rVqnested that the necessary ateps be ta ken Mi seeure its abrogation and replacement bÿ\he lollowing : ' Nu one s hall in Egypt exercise the pro-ioD of pharmacist, carry on a pharmacy, • tjr scU any médicament nnleas he bas s diploma from a reo guisod faculty and has oklained authorisaüon from the Sanitary Administration. Also nç phannaciat «hall carry on or possess more than one pharmacy." The petitiorers asserted that they did not wish to modify the status of exiating phar macies run by uuqualified proprietor*; so long as they- bave a reaponaible pharmacist it) charge ; bat they désire that for the fntnn only qualified chemists «hall be able to bny 01 open a pharmacy. They stated thoir oonvictior also that a pharmacist delegated by thon associations shonld be présent at ail inspec lions of pharmacies. A pétition to this effect " itjgned by the President of the Association anc by the English chemists establiahed in Cairo was duly presented to Lord Grenier, wh replied at leugth. Ho began by expreasing hii entiro agreeœent with the principle advocatoc —tbat, on the whole, a System under whicl the ownetship of pharmacies is restrioted U qualified pharmaciste offera greater guarantee to the pnblio than one under which the owue —»y be unqualified. He believed that thi ew was largely share-1 by the publio, an. „c the mention npon lhe façade of an ests Miment that the owner is not bimself qua ted will go far towards securing what th armacists desire. The practical question «ever, was not what System would theoreti cally be most satistsetory, but wbat System cai be most effectively onforoed in Egypt, ha vin, regard to the- restrictions on its legislativ powers under whioh the Egyptian Goverumen labours In this oonnection Lord Cromorquota from the letter addrau-ed to the petitioner» b tho Director-tieneral of the Sanitary Départ ment on December H, 1904, iu which hé deal witb the point in question os follows :— "As regards the ownership of pharmacie», bave to oUerve that the rigbts of foreigtiei under the Capitulations again necesssrily limi the action of the Goven.meut The Üovsrniqen bas power, with the consent of tks'Mixed Coin ol Appeal, to inake régulations of generz application in the interest of public health, bu it bas vqry Iittle power of desHng with right cl property. Now, it happons that the sut ceasful conduct of a pharmacy requires no only profeisional skill, but also some amour ' f capital, and in (thé course of time thei adhères toit a right of property of the moi val h able kind — that of the goodwill of th burinera. It did not appear to the Governmer o--r ntial for the protection of the public healt that the pro'essional skill and the reqnisit capital shonld be nnited in the sanie haïuti That being so, it waa clear that if their unie »u to lie insiated on it would hâve bee to avoid dealing witb the question of goodwi Uni»ss the hoirs of a pharmacist who die witboot baving provided a sucoessor were t bave been seriously prejudioed. W* w*re adri ed that any attempt to doal with this question would bave raised questions as to rigbts of property which might havo been tatl to the régulations as a whole. My deparunent was the more ready to accédé to tbis view beoause we were oonvinoed that any ru les in the aense you suggest wquld hâve been partioularly easy of évasion. Once a phannaciat has taken out bis lioense to praotise, he ,ia free io open a pharmacy after notification to tho Department, and the Departmeut has no right to inquiro as to tho source from which lhe necessary capital ia obtained, nor as to tho terme upon ,which it ta ubtainod. Were a sériés of young pharmacists, known to be in possession ot no capital, suooes-sively to oocnpy the same pharmacy, lakiug over in tnm tho stock of drugs, etc., there would be a very stxoug presumption that they were in tact the salaned servants of the true preprietor ot the establishment, bat we were advised that no such presumption oould be drawn in law. The frank récognition of the facta by the régulations has at leoat the ad-vautage that, if tho propriotor dolares himself, the régulations subjeot him to a certain moasure of-contre), which would be otherwiae impossible.” Lord Cramer then prooeeded to show that it|was clear that the question under dis-cussion was decided by the Legal Adviær to the Government rathor thau by tho Saui-tary Department on prolcaaional g round». On the legal point he hesitated to express apy Personal opinion, but-ho had before hiré a oopy ot defini te proposais lormulated some time before by the committeo of tlie Alexandrin International Association of Chemists tor the amendmeot of tho new law. lu that ho obaervod that the oommittee was ffnprëë^ sed by the possible hardship which 'might rêvait for the widow and orphans of a pharmacist under the rule propoeed, and that ,it drafted somewhat elaboraie provisions for meeting the case, W hâte ver opinion one might furm as to the uiility of tho provisions then suggested, it «a* at lca-it clear that they proposed to croate a form of property in a pharmacists business which might for rnauy years remain in the hauds of perso ns other thau qualified pharmacist». AU his expérience of the *very limi ted scope within which rognlations approved by the Mixed Court of Appeal requiro to be kept, led him tu beliovè that any régulations on the subject under discussion must either recogniso a goodwill in a pharma-cist’s business whioh «hall be freely transférable, or «hall retuse to reoognise any such ■ goodwill at ail, and that the syatem of lree 1 trauafer of goodwill is probably the one whioh ’ will work most efficieutly and with least 1 friction. He depresatod the anticipation of the petitaoncra that the System embodied in the - new Uw would canne «eriocs préjudice to - qi.a'ifiod pharmacists employed as managers. He thought theïr fears were somewhat exag- 1 gorated. The view taken by such managers themselves, as éxpreased in a pétition to the t Direotor-General of the Sanitary Department, » was that the new law, by regulatiug a situa-f don which already existed, had already im-* proved their position pecuniarily. Although be i could not oonoeal from himsolf tho fact that 1 the petitiunere were likely to remain hostile to ■ the particular provision iu question, he trusted they wonld reoogui-e that it was furoed upon 1 the Government by the facta of the situation,. 1 rathsr than adoptod by eboioe, and that they i may find in practioe that it wiU not produca tho regrettable conséquences they are inclincd ■ to anticipât*.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Lien tenant-Colonel J. K. Watson, C. M. G., D. 8. 0., King’s Royal Rifle Corps, who has just taken up the dnties of aide-deomp to lhe Khedive, is, 1 believe, the fini British jfficer who bas been appointed to that oifioe. Lioutanant-Coloi-ol Watoon has worn the green jackct for just'SO yeara, having got his Irat appointaient ia April, 1885. His oompany jamo to him in 1893 and his prêtent «nbstan-tive rank in Ootober, 1902. His finit active serrioe was in the Chtn Hill Expédition, 1891* 92,’and fonr years later he went throagh the D-mgola Expédition as aide-do-oamp to Sir Herbert Kitohener (mentioned in despatches. D. 8 0., modal, and Khe-iive’s modal). He beld a similar appointaient in Kitchener’s advanoe to Khartoum vii the Atbara and Omdorman (twioe mentioned in despatches, brevet majority. and two clasps), and he earned another mention and the 4 th Clasa of the Oimauieh in tho operations of 1899, when be wai D. A. A. G. to the flying colnmd whioh fi cally sqaared aooocnts with the He was again aideriecamp to Lord Kitohener in the Boer War of 1809-1901 (mentioned in despatches, medal with clasps), and in April of the latt-r year joined the Egyptian Army at Cairo as an A. A. G. on the beadqcarter staff. Lioutcnant-Colonel Watson iiam ffioerof tried ability, and his appoint-ment to the Khedive’s Personal staff is a decided compliment. London, April 17. Captain and Brevet Major Hesaey, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, who recently vacatod the appointaient of aidede-camp to Major General Leach, V.C., lato oommanding the Belfast Distriot, has been ordered to join the 2nd Batta'ion at iro on absorption. Major Hessey was with the lst Battalion in the lato Boer War, inolndings the battle of Colenso, where he was «everely woonded, the actions ot Vaal-Rrantx, Tugela Heights, Pieter’s Hill, and those of Belfast and Lydenberg, in the campaign east of Pretoria (mentioned in despatches, medal with fonr olasps). In addition to Captain C. G. M. Blomfield, 4th Battalion Royal Warsriokshire Régiment, Curragh, Captain J. P. Hawksley, 113th Battery B.F.A, Shorncliffe, and Lieutenant C. IL Lucas, 2ud Battalion Royal Berkshire Régiment, hâve boen selooted for service with tho Khedive’s troop*. Captain Hawksley joined the Royal Artillery in September, 1897, was promoted oaptain last July, and uw alotof service in the late Boer War. He was with the 42nd Field Batteqr at the actions of Elands-laatge, Rietfontein, and Lombard’* Kop, which preoeded the siégé of Ladysmith, and after-srards participa ted in tbe defenoe of that garrison and the operations to the east of Pretoria and the actions of Lydeuberg and Belfast (modal with four olasps and mentioned in despatches). Lieutenant Lucas has served seven yeara in the Royal Berka and holds the medal with three clasps for the osmpaign in the Transvaal, Orange River Colony and Cape Colony. A despatch from the Meditemcean States that the majority of the ahips on that station made good practioe at the recent qoar+erly firing. Not a~few of the ships needed a bit of pnlHng cp m straight shooting.
